titleStmt.title: Despatch from Alexander Clark to William F. Wharton, December 31, 1890

bibl.title: Despatch from Alexander Clark to William F. Wharton
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p:
Consulate General of the United States,
Monrovia Liberia December 31, 1890.
Mr Alexander Clark
To the Department of State.

These accounts are to include the Sept Quarter ending Sept 30th Rent. and the December Quarter ending December 31/90 also vouchers for said accounts as far as I could &c indeed it is all most imposible to secure vouchers for every small expense of the Legation as I am to each without bills. Also please inform if I am to give oath before a notary republic for amount of fee collected, as I a list of fees to the and also to by report &c The above information I desire much that may be governed by &c

Consulate General of the United States,
Monrovia Liberia December 31, 1890.
To the
Honorable William F. Wharton
Assistant Secretary of State.
Washington DC

I have the honor to advise that I have drawn Draft No. 2. for contingent expenses $228 37/100 Dollars on the Secretary of State in favor of R. A. Sherman; also Draft No 3. on account of salary $478 Dollars on the Secretary of State in favor of myself endorsed to George W. Appleton All of said Drafts for the Quarters ending Sept. 30/90 and December 31 1890 per accompanying accounts. I have further to request that you suply the legation with some blank Drafts as there is not one left. and I was compeled to use. Dole of exchange for my Sallary draft, &c. also there is no abstract blanks left except 2. and sallery. blanks and fees. I am satisfied the department can furnish them by mail cheaper than they can be printed because they would have to be printed in Liverpool or London as there are no printers established here &c & & I have the honor to be your obedient servant, Alexander Clark Minister Resident CG
